results.name: Following the successive antidiagonals in A065188, let the n-th queen appear in square (x(n),y(n)); sequence gives x(n).
comment: This is a permutation of the natural numbers.
This assumes the indexing starts at 1. See A275901, A275902 if the indexing begins at 0.
link: N. J. A. Sloane, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..7500
maple: # To get the coordinates of queens in order of appearance; b8[] has list of terms of A065188
for n from 1 to M do
